15.text:
SUBJECT: So I'm interested
in the kinds of ideas

18.text:
that dissolve boundaries, that
remind us of what is possible,

22.text:
that encourage us to
think differently,

26.text:
to probe at the
adjacent possible.

28.text:
There's great line that says,
once a mind is stretched

31.text:
by a new idea, it
will never return

35.text:
The kind of things that
make us question everything.

39.text:
And Tom Robbins has
a great description.

41.text:
He says a cyclone
of unorthodox ideas

44.text:
that will raise every every,
any mind out of its cognitive

50.text:
In other words, we
are like Dorothy,

52.text:
and we crave the
kind of whirlwind

54.text:
of ideas that will transport us,
transfigurate us, and land us

59.text:
in Oz, a place where there is
room for mystery, a place where

63.text:
there's room for
juxtaposition and surrealism,

66.text:
a reenchanted world, again,
where everything is possible.

74.text:
They are planted in there
and transform us from within.

77.text:
And now all of us are
broadcasters, right?

81.text: We don't just passively take in.

85.text:
And so it's up to us to
get the kind of ideas

87.text:
out of into the world that
will spread mimetically

90.text:
and that will collectively
upgrade mankind.

93.text:
It's our responsibility, as the
co-authors of the memespace,

97.text:
to tell great stories, to
enliven the imagination,

101.text:
to stretch our brains
beyond the cognitive Kansas.
